headline.main: Chemical Treatment Is Wrong Answer to Cocaine Addiction

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: What are America's most pressing domestic needs? In his new budget, President Bush lays out these answers: (1) to increase productivity; (2) to invest in people; and (3) to end the scourge of drugs. Admirable. Many Americans share these goals. But there's a problem. Though the captain's new chart plots a sensible destination, his boat is too small to get there.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For 50 years, Dr. Milton Reder, a prominent New York physician, has used cocaine to treat pain. The practice was recently banned by New York State health officials, but Dr. Reder has ignored the ban, moving into the forefront of physicians who say the treatments should be allowed until more research has been done.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For the police and Federal drug agents here, it remains a curious but persistent truth: Crack use has never reached the epidemic proportion in Chicago that it has in many other major urban areas.

headline.main: Crack Epidemic Missing Chicago In Urban Sweep

docs.snippet: LEAD: For the police and Federal drug agents here, it remains a curious but persistent truth: Crack use has never reached the epidemic proportion in Chicago that it has in many other major urban areas.

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to the New York Times
